title: 103_hr3082
content: The Act titled "Women Veterans Health Improvements Act of 1993" focuses on providing health care services for women veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that all health-care facilities provide timely and appropriate health care services to eligible veterans. This includes routine services for women veterans in specific catchment areas. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that health-care facilities provide routine healthcare services directly to eligible veterans as described in section 1710(a)(1) of title 38, United States Code. Facilities must be equipped with appropriate resources and staff to maintain professional standards of care. Section 302 of the Veterans' Health Care Amendments of 1983 is repealed. SEC. 3. MAMMOGRAPHY QUALITY STANDARDS. Mammograms at VA facilities must be accredited by a designated organization meeting specific standards. Quality assurance and control standards for mammograms are to be prescribed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Department of Veterans Affairs must ensure compliance with mammogram standards through equipment inspections. Mammograms performed by non-Federal providers for the VA must meet quality standards set by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must report to Congress on the implementation of mammogram standards within 120 days. The term "mammogram" is defined as per the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 4. Sexual trauma counseling amended to extend deadlines. Repeal of Section 102(b) of the Veterans Health Care Act of 1992. SEC. 5. Coordinators of women's services. SEC. 5. COORDINATORS OF WOMEN'S SERVICES. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that coordinators of women's services serve full-time and have the ability to provide quality medical care and equal access to facilities for women veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must identify and correct deficiencies in patient privacy for women patients in medical centers. Plans to address these deficiencies should be prioritized in construction planning processes. Annual reports on deficiencies and correction plans must be submitted to Congress by October 1, 1994. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must report deficiencies in patient privacy for women patients to Congress annually by October 1, including an inventory, proposed corrective plans, and their status.
